questions.question: I usually get up ………………… six o’clock.
questions.description: We use at with clock times.

questions.question: Phone me ……………… lunchtime.
questions.description: We use at with clock times.

questions.question: I work best ………………. the evening.
questions.description: We use ‘in’ with parts of the day. For example, we say in the morning, in the afternoon and in the evening.

questions.question: I usually go for a walk ……………….. the morning.
questions.description: We use ‘in’ with parts of the day. For example, we say in the morning, in the afternoon and in the evening.

questions.question: We met …………….. a cold afternoon in winter.
questions.description: We use ‘on’ when we say which morning / afternoon / etc., we are talking about.

questions.question: What are you doing …………….. the weekend?
questions.description: We can say at the weekend or on the weekend.

questions.question: They got married ……………… the week after Easter.
questions.description: We use in for longer periods.

questions.question: We are having the house painted …………… Easter.
questions.description: We use ‘at’ to talk about the whole of the holidays at Christmas, Easter etc.

questions.question: I wrote the book …………. a month.
Are you free .......................?
questions.description: Prepositions are not used in expressions of time before next, last, this, that, each, every etc.
